captions.text: Was that thunder?
That sharpens everything up and away you go...

Today is a very good day. I'm driving a Porsche
Boxster, roof down, good weather, on a mountain

road in Mallorca. It doesn't really get much
better than this, you know.

However, before any customer gets to experience
this, they have to go through the painful

procedure of specifying up their perfect car.
And as with any Porsche, that's a tricky and

costly business. And now, that decision is
even more difficult for Boxster S and Cayman

S buyers, thanks to the launch of the new
GTS models.

They cost around £6,000 more and come with
some unique front and rear bumpers, plus a

15bhp upgrade to their 3.4-litre engines,
which means the Boxster now has 330bhp and
the Cayman 340bhp.

The GTS models also feature a feast of extra
kit, which you may or may not want to fit

to your S anyway. And so today, I'm going
to try and find out the if the added value

of the GTS makes it a no-brainer to upgrade
over the S.

For instance, you get the Porsche sports exhaust
as standard and that'll normally cost you

£1,530 and you definitely want that, because
its changes the sound of the flat-six engine

from this, which is pretty nice, to this when
I press the button -

I think that's nicer and it even makes this
noise when you kick it down a gear.

Was that thunder? I definitely don't see rain
clouds...

The 
GTS also has alcantara and leather trim on
the dash. If you want hide on the dash of

your S model, which you do if you want the
car to feel as posh as it should, you'll need
extended leather and that's a £1,740 option.

So, already, if you were buying a Boxster
S, you'd have spent over £3,000 on extras
anyway.

However, things are about to get a little
bit confusing because the GTS comes with some

items you wouldn't necessarily want, such
as smoked rear-light clusters - £320. I wouldn't

bother with those. Then there's the Sports
Seat Plus, £546 for those. They are nice,

but they're not really necessary. £447 for
direction headlamp beams. You've got to be

kidding, right? There's no way I'm buying
those.

£971 to go from the 19-inch to 20-inch alloy
wheels and they do look nice, don't they?

But you're going to end up kerbing those.
When you add all those options up, they come

to pretty much the same price as the satellite
navigation system and frankly, I'd rather
have that as it'll be more useful every day.

All what I've just said about the Boxster
applies equally to the Cayman. But there are

some other extras I've not yet mentioned which
equally affect the handling and after all,
that is what this coupe version is all about.

The GTS also gets Porsche Active Suspension
Management as standard and normally, that

would cost you £971 and it's an option you
definitely want because it lowers the car

by 10mm for improved responses. Because you've
got adapted dampers, when you're just cruising

along with it in normal mode, it's nice and
comfy.

And then when you press this button down here,
it sharpens everything up and away you go.

If you regularly take your car on a circuit,
instead of the active suspension, you can

have the sports chassis which lowers the car
by a further 10mm but has fixed rate dampers.

It's great for Track Day junkies and if your
name is Walter Röhrl, but forget it if you
mainly drive on the road.

Last but not least, there's the Sports Chrono
package. Now, that would normally cost you

£1,085 and as part of it, you get active
engine mounts and what they do, is hold the

engine firmly in place when you're braking,
accelerating or cornering, and that apparently

improves the car's balance, but I think I
can live without that. I'm not entirely sure

I'm going to be able to discern that when
I'm out driving out on the road.

I'd rather Porsche fitted the car with the
£890 torque vectoring to improve the amount

of grip you have. Sports Chrono also includes
a stopwatch on the dash, which you don't really

need. There's also a slightly sharper throttle
response and a more lenient stability control

system - both of which I think are items you
won't miss either.

Cars with PDK gearboxes also get launch control
and that enables the Cayman to sprint from

0-62mph in just 4.6 seconds. To activate it
it's dead easy - you just put the car in drive,

put it in Sports Plus mode, put your left
foot on the brake, mash the throttle and when

it says launch control, you then release the
brake and away you go.

The thing is, the only time I ever use launch
control is to give a demonstration to you

guys. In every day driving, I've never used
it once so it's pointless. That brings us

back to whether the GTS is worth a £6,000
premium over the S.

Well, seeing as you'd only need to spend £4,000
to get the right optional equipment, you're

effectively paying £2,000 extra for a GTS
badge, some unique bumpers and an extra 15bhp.

Do you know what? I'd be lying if I told you
I could feel the extra 15bhp out here on the

road. I'd also be lying if I told you I really
cared the GTS badge had a bit of history attached

to it. For me, I'd rather take that £2,000
and spend it on the excellent PDK paddleshift

automatic gearbox. And so for me, the GTS
isn't really worth it. I'd be better off getting

a normal Cayman or Boxster S, and speccing
it up exactly as I want it.

However, that's just my opinion. People who
want to be able to say they own the ultimate

Boxster or Cayman won't have any trouble in
justifying the extra cash for the GTS.

So, I suppose the final question is, is should
you go for the Boxster or the Cayman? Quite

frankly, that comes down to whether you want
a coupe or a convertible and personally for

me after having driven both cars back-to-back
on these fabulous roads, I got a little bit

more out of being able to take the roof down,
than the sharper dynamics you get from having
the roof fixed.

In this particular instance, I'm going to
take the Boxster.

Click on the video windows to watch our in-depth
of the Porsche Boxster and the Cayman track-battle.

Click on the play icon to watch our very latest
video review and on the Auto Express logo
to subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: Porsche Cayman GTS and Boxster GTS review - are they worth it?
